full_text: In this demo, I will demonstrate how to find the availability settings in the product model, using Product Designer. I will show you where to specify conditions that make a coverage available or not available. A coverage's availability depends on different factors such as dates, jurisdiction, underwriting company, and job type. There are ways to configure availability using a script or grandfathering coverage that is otherwise not available. Let's take a look at a personal auto policy as an example. I am going to take a look at this collision coverage. This collision coverage has an availability set with no specifics. However, let's take a look at another coverage to see how things can differ. In this collision coverage, the availability is set to two states, Massachusetts and Michigan. Here is another example where the coverage is mostly unavailable but available in Michigan. Note that jurisdiction is not the only way to control availability. Let's take a look at one more example in the business owners line of business. This example shows where to add grandfathering and where to add an availability script. If I wanted to make a coverage available through grandfathering, I would do it here. I can add specific criteria like jurisdiction, underwriting company, or the end effective date, in order to make the coverage available. Finally, the example of where to add an availability script is located here. In the availability script section, the specific instructions for availability can be added. Note that availability lookup tables are good for simple comparisons. Product model patterns specify an availability script to handle more complex conditions. For example, a script would be necessary if the coverage pattern is only available for vehicles manufactured after 1986. For more information about availability, please consult the Policy Center documentation. segments.text: In this demo, I will demonstrate how to find the availability settings in the product model, using Product Designer.

I will show you where to specify conditions that make a coverage available or not available. A coverage's availability depends on different factors such as dates, jurisdiction, underwriting company, and job type.
There are ways to configure availability using a script or grandfathering coverage that is otherwise not available. Let's take a look at a personal auto policy as an example.
I am going to take a look at this collision coverage.
This collision coverage has an availability set with no specifics. However, let's take a look at another coverage to see how things can differ.

In this collision coverage, the availability is set to two states, Massachusetts and Michigan. Here is another example where the coverage is mostly unavailable but available in Michigan. Note that jurisdiction is not the only way to control availability.
Let's take a look at one more example in the business owners line of business. This example shows where to add grandfathering and where to add an availability script.

If I wanted to make a coverage available through grandfathering, I would do it here. I can add specific criteria like jurisdiction, underwriting company, or the end effective date, in order to make the coverage available.
Finally, the example of where to add an availability script is located here. In the availability script section, the specific instructions for availability can be added.
Note that availability lookup tables are good for simple comparisons.
Product model patterns specify an availability script to handle more complex conditions.
For example, a script would be necessary if the coverage pattern is only available for vehicles manufactured after 1986.
For more information about availability, please consult the Policy Center documentation.
